At that time, King Prasenajit was in the house of the courtesan in Taká¹£aÅ›ilÄ. Seeing that Chanda had come, he asked:

Chanda heard this and then went with the king on the same elephant and left along the road.

Following the road, he went further and saw an elephant passing under a tree by the side of the road. A black snake hanging from the tree branch wanted to bite the king. Udayana saw this and immediately drew his sword, cut it into several pieces, and fell to the ground wriggling. Udayana said:
This should not be done, yet you insist on doing it.

On another day, the elephant ran fast and refused to go slowly.
Just about to reach the city, Udayana said to the king:

'The elephant will run a hundred yojanas and return to the South Sea to drink water to fill its hunger.'
Look at this rapid pace, it definitely will not stop. I will have to hold onto a tree branch and jump down.

The king said to Udayana:ğŸ”½You should go back to the palace first, I will return later.

At that time, the king was ashamed and did not enter through the main gate. He then wanted to enter the palace through a water window.
At that time, there were two women who did not recognize him as the king. They said to each other:

One said:

I told Vará¹£ÄkÄra to secretly inform the queen, but he went and told everyone in the city and towns.
On another day, feeling unable to bear it, he told Vará¹£ÄkÄra:

'These people make a living by using the great earth.'
Again, in a certain place, he said like this:
'This should not be done, leading to worry and sorrow.

Again, in a certain place, he said like this:
'This should not be done, yet they insist on doing it.'
How could it be that I, going to the brothel, is what should not be done?

'I am now staying in the garden.'

UpacelÄ, frightened, said like this:

Previously, at the potter's, I saw some unfired pottery, an elephant's foot stepped on it and broke it. The potter saw it and was worried. I, seeing this matter, said like this:
'These people make a living by relying on clay.'
On the way, I saw a small bird that had laid eggs on the road. An elephant stepped on and crushed them. The bird cried out in grief. Seeing this, I said:

Later, on a tree branch, I saw a snake slithering down to bite the king. I cut it into several pieces and left them on the ground. I said:

As for the claim that I entered the palace and secretly informed the queen, and then spread the word throughout the city, that is also not true.

The king said:

Moreover, after I left, a brahmin said:

He replied:
The brahmin should wait, first kill the flying evil people.
The king said:

He replied:

The king said:

At that time, in this city there was the son of a great minister who was previously skilled in incantations. Vá¹›ddha went to him and asked:

He then cut off the hand of a dead person, transformed it into an utpala flower, and had someone sell it, telling him:
You should take this to the market to sell. If someone comes to buy it with money, do not give it to them.

That person did everything according to the instructions. In this city, he recorded the names of those who laughed and got five hundred people.
When the king heard this, he told UpacelÄ:

He then prepared a place outside the city, making it clean and tidy, and issued a proclamation:
The king now wishes to hold an unrestricted great assembly to request the celestial spirits. All of you sisters should come and gather.
When the women heard the king's order, they all gathered, wanting to seek wealth. Although they had no names, they came out of greed, and there were over five hundred people.
The son of the great minister bound them all with spell ropes and had them killed by a man with a knife.
The king said:
Although these demons have been exterminated, there are still various Brahmins.
He then ordered them to be informed everywhere:
I have created immeasurable unwholesome karma and have already killed five hundred flying demonesses.
In order to save me, you should come to one place every day to receive food.
Hearing this, they all came to receive it with joy.
The king ordered the gatekeeper, saying:
You should count the number of Brahmin assemblies receiving food and report it to me.
The gatekeeper respectfully agreed, and the king said again:
You people in the city should prepare the best food to offer to the Brahmins.
At that time, the Brahmins, greedy for good food, accepted the king's invitation and all came to the gathering.
After the meal, they wanted to leave. The gatekeepers counted them and found there were exactly 80,000, so they reported to the king:
The count is exactly 80,000.
Hearing this, the king thought:
How can I kill so many lives at one time?
He then ordered that when each Brahmin was eating, a butcher should hold a knife behind them and tell them:
If you hear me say 'take the curd,' you should all strike their heads at the same time.
Having given this instruction, they did as told and even cut off their heads.
After the king had killed the Brahmins, he dreamed that night of the earth shaking and six syllables coming out of the sky.
There were also eight dreams.
As for the earth shaking and six syllables, it meant six non-selves, my contemptible mind.
The six syllables that emerge are all who are equal now they and I.
What are the eight dreams?
Namely, first, seeing white sandalwood paste applied all over the body;
second, seeing red sandalwood water sprinkled on the body;
third, seeing the head on fire;
fourth, seeing large poisonous snakes hanging from the armpits;
fifth, seeing two carp licking the two feet;
sixth, seeing two white geese flying in from the sky;
seventh, seeing a large black mountain coming straight towards the face;
eighth, seeing white gulls dropping excrement on the head.
At that time, after the king had had these many dreams, he was greatly frightened and his body hair stood on end. He thought like this:
Could it be that because of this, the royal position will be lost and my life will be harmed?
He then summoned the brahman who could interpret dreams and told him about it. He thought like this:
This is a good dream for the king, but I will say it is bad.
If you say it is good, it will further increase his arrogance and prolong his evil views, and the other brahmins will be killed again.
Having thought this, they discussed together and replied:
Great King!
This is not a good dream.
The king said:
Tell me, what will be the retribution?
They answered:
This dream indicates that the king's position will be lost and his body will perish.
When the king heard this, he became greatly distressed.
At that time, the king had another thought:
Is there a way to preserve my body and not lose my royal position?
I should now go to Venerable Katyayana and ask about good and bad omens. Could it be an evil sign for me?
Having arrived there, he bowed his head to Katyayana's feet, sat to one side, and told him about the dream in detail.
The Venerable One replied:
Great King!

I also ask about the others.

He replied:

The king then told him what they had said.
The Venerable One replied:
Great King!
They always enjoy sensual pleasures and aspire to be reborn in the heavens. What else do they know?
The king's dreams are auspicious signs, you need not be afraid. This will not cause you to lose your position or die.
Why is it so?
As the king has heard, there were six sounds from the earth. What are these omens?
You should know that this is a warning to the king, urging him to change his evil ways and follow goodness.
In the past, there were six kings who ruled the world with unrighteousness. When their bodies decayed and their lives ended, they fell into hell.
This first king, while in hell, experiencing great suffering, spoke a verse, which is the first 'six' characters.
For sixty-six thousand years, I was burned in the hells;
Now experiencing great and extreme suffering, I do not know when it will end.
The second king also spoke a verse, which is the second no character.
There is no end to suffering, I will never know the end of the days;
My kind is the same, this is due to previous evil karma.
The third king also spoke a verse, which is the third I character.
The clothes and food I obtain, whether by right or wrong;
Others enjoy the pleasure of eating, causing me to alone encounter misfortune.
The fourth king also spoke a verse, which is the fourth shame character.
Shame on my form and life, there is something I cannot let go of;
Not giving food and drink to others, causing my body to have no benefit.
The fifth king also spoke a verse, which is the fifth syllable 'xin' (å¿ƒ).
The mind always deceives me, and I am constantly dragged by ignorance;
When suffering in hell, there is no one willing to take my place.
The sixth king also spoke a verse, which is the sixth syllable 'ruo' (è‹¥).

Moreover, great king!
The six sounds in the sky, whose past omens are they?
You should understand it like this.
In the king's residence, there was a large bamboo pole, which was eaten by many tiny insects. The soft parts were all consumed, leaving only the hard parts.

That person, day after day, in a crow's nest, broke the eggs. The crow, seeing its young die, gave rise to resentment in its heart, all crying out and speaking this verse, which is the second 'who' character.
Who else can do this for me, piercing a person's eye to make it blind?
Not killing my offspring, removing the worry and distress from my heart.
The king should stop it and not allow it to happen again.

In the king's garden there is a pleasure pond, the water of which was originally level and full, inhabited by many fish, turtles, and frogs. There was a white egret bird that always ate the fish.
Now the pond is dry without water, and the bird, seeing this, sighed and spoke a verse, which is the third character 'ping'.
The flat ground is always full of water, with many fish and turtles;

The king should now add water to it and drive the bird away.

In this country there is a great mountain called Fearsome, where there is a male elephant and a female elephant both born blind, with only one child who always serves as their attendant. The flock all enjoy pleasure, grazing on water and grass as they please;
Only I am bound, worrying alone day and night.
The king should release them to go to the mountains and forests.

In the king's residence, there is a goose bound, looking up into the sky, seeing a flock of geese flying away, feeling sorrowful and speaking a verse:

The bird friends have all gone, drinking and pecking as they please;
What crime has my body committed?

The king should arouse compassion and also release it.

Moreover, great king, as for the eight things you dreamed, what are their omens? As for dreaming of smearing white sandalwood paste all over the body, the king of a superior country will send a great white blanket to offer to the great king!

In the past, there was a famous mountain with clear springs and lush fruit trees.

'My dear!

She replied:

The two doves both said:

The two argued and eventually fought, and at that time the male dove pecked the female's head with its beak, causing her to die.
The male dove stayed by the side, watching the fruit, and suddenly it rained and the nest was filled with fruit again. The male dove thought:
'Now the nest is full again, it is definitely not that she ate it.'
He then went to the female dove to apologize and said:

At that time, the gods saw this in the sky and spoke a verse, saying:

Not knowing the end of form and life, one repents and apologizes, giving rise to suffering.

Already having them executed, you only give rise to sorrow and distress yourself.

In the past, there was an elder who, when autumn arrived, carried yellow beans to the fields to plant, placing them under a tree where he was turning around.ğŸ”½A monkey on the tree came down to steal the seeds, grabbed a handful and went back up the tree.

The king previously sent me to kill the queen, and because of a small angry thought, I lost great benefits. Can I now seek to see her again?
The king said to Nanda:

Hasn't the king heard that 'The great master has no two, and what he says is only one;
It is definitely not mixed up, and the king's words are also like this'?
The king said:

You immediately followed my words, how can this be reasonable?

He then answered in verse:

The first is being born blind, and the second is not knowing the Dharma.
In this world and the next life, there are also two kinds of darkness:
One is the view of evil, the other is the destruction of morality.
The second internal sub-chapter summary verse says:

Suffering, harm, giving rise to doubt, contempt, matters should be gradual.
The king said to Nanda:
You killed Queen PadmÄvatÄ«, and now I am naked.
He replied:
Has the king not heard that in the world, three naked bodies are not considered good signs?
What are the three?

A woman whose husband has passed away has no place to turn to.

Moreover, to remember one's various past lives, such as one birth, two births, up to ten births, twenty, thirty, up to a hundred births, a thousand births, ten thousand births, countless tens of thousands of births, eons of world formation, eons of world destruction, up to countless eons of world formation and destruction, all of which one can recall:

Moreover, attaining the pure heavenly eye, surpassing that of humans, able to observe the deaths and rebirths of beings, their forms, good and evil, their lowly and exalted lineages, being born in good or evil destinies following their karma, knowing it as it truly is.

Moreover, having attained the exhaustion of all contaminations, in the state of being free from contaminations, one attains mental liberation, and is able to realize and perfect the Dharma by oneself. One's births are exhausted, the practice of austerity is established, what was to be done is done, and one does not receive future existences. I know this as it truly is, this is the tenth power.
